abstract: THE boxes are the first things a visitor sees when entering Mrs. G's apartment. At the top of a rickety staircase, they wait in the shadows, piled high with her belongings - testimony to the chaos she has endured.   ''I'm not living now, I'm surviving,'' said the 28-year-old mother, who has been separated from her husband on and off for almost two years.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

abstract: Dr. Percy Klingenstein turned 100 last month and The New York Times Neediest  Cases Fund received $500 from his daughter-in-law, Ann Holmes. She wanted to celebrate and honor Dr. Klingenstein's devotion to his hometown.         "He was born and raised in New York City, and the only time he left the city  was to serve in World War II." wrote Ms. Holmes, of Short Hills, N.J. "Many years ago, when he was more active, he could not walk by a 'beggar' without giving him a dollar or two. With all of the homeless on the streets today, this  kind gesture would be impossible."
lead_paragraph: Dr. Percy Klingenstein turned 100 last month and The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received $500 from his daughter-in-law, Ann Holmes. She wanted to celebrate and honor Dr. Klingenstein's devotion to his hometown.

abstract: Juana Rosario brought her granddaughter to the United States to get specialized medical help for the girl, but the family, with scant income, is living in a city homeless shelter.
snippet: Juana Rosario brought her granddaughter to the United States to get specialized medical help for the girl, but the family, with scant income, is living in a city homeless shelter.
lead_paragraph: The last few years have been traumatic ones for Juana Rosario, who has been living in the New York City shelter system since 2010, alongside her husband and her disabled granddaughter, Amy Germosen Rosario. But as nightmarish as the experience has been, she prefers it to going back home to the Dominican Republic.

abstract: Beaulah Smith, who cared for her dying husband while battling ovarian cancer, depleted her savings trying to pay expenses and soon fell behind on rent.
snippet: Beaulah Smith, who cared for her dying husband while battling ovarian cancer, depleted her savings trying to pay expenses and soon fell behind on rent.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 13, Beaulah Smith was seated beside her husband, Isaac, as he lay in a hospital bed listening to a team of doctors explain the grim state of his health. Ms. Smith, 63, knew that her husband was weak after having several strokes, and she suspected that the pain he was experiencing might be the result of an ulcer. But as she sat beside her husband of 40 years, she was totally unprepared for the words she would hear.

snippet: After a helping hand, a Brooklyn teenager's talent for music blossoms.
lead_paragraph: With sheet music resting near her pillow, Nia Drummond, 14, hovers over a keyboard set on a floral comforter. Singing “New York State of Mind,” the teenager’s powerful voice echoes off the bare walls, filling the sparsely furnished two-bedroom apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where she has lived her entire life.

snippet: Skylynn Vazquez and Saquan Bright found the right fit at Brooklyn High School for Leadership and Community Service, which helps students who have dropped out or who are at risk of doing so.
lead_paragraph: She skipped almost every class her sophomore year and still maintained perfect attendance. The trick was to drop in for the start of third period, wait for attendance to be recorded for the day and then leave with a bathroom pass. By the time her mother found out about the scheme, Skylynn Vazquez was failing every subject.

abstract: Since being told 36 years ago that she had Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, a rare collagen disorder, Margie Jones has dealt with many obstacles, the latest being a threat to her eyesight.
snippet: Since being told 36 years ago that she had Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, a rare collagen disorder, Margie Jones has dealt with many obstacles, the latest being a threat to her eyesight.
lead_paragraph: For better and worse, flexibility has defined Margie Jones’s life. A rare genetic disorder makes her hyperflexible, to the point that she cannot always support her own body parts, and her joints easily disconnect from their sockets. But Ms. Jones’s equally agile mind has found ways to adapt to each new challenge, physical and financial, that has emerged over her 78 years.

lead_paragraph: In the third trimester of her pregnancy, Daniel Harris, then 16, struggled to comfortably sleep through the night. So she was awake just after 4 a.m., when the sound of screaming became audible. She thought a next-door neighbor was responsible for the commotion, until her frightened younger sister went to her bedroom and a sick realization hit.

abstract: After the Gathers family lost its Van Nest apartment to a fire and was left without a long-term home, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund provided assistance.
snippet: After the Gathers family lost its Van Nest apartment to a fire and was left without a long-term home, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund provided assistance.
lead_paragraph: Last Aug. 29 was supposed to be a night of celebration. But when Chaka and Carina Gathers returned from the hospital with their newborn son Cason, their third child, they found their Bronx apartment building in flames.

headline.main: Burned Out of Their Home in the Bronx, but Grateful to Be Together

abstract: Though theirs is an immigrant success story in some respects, with sons working and one owning a business, Maha al-Obaidi grieves that half her family remains half a world away.

lead_paragraph: Maha al-Obaidi’s family is divided.

byline.original: By John Otis and Rana F. Sweis

abstract: Emotional and financial burdens have plagued Marie Troy, who suffered complications from gastric bypass surgery, and her 17-year-old daughter, who has severe asthma.
snippet: Emotional and financial burdens have plagued Marie Troy, who suffered complications from gastric bypass surgery, and her 17-year-old daughter, who has severe asthma.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, Marie Troy, 51, and her daughter Nicole Abbate, 17, seem to have hit a rough patch  the product of bad luck, perhaps, or a bad year. But a short conversation with them reveals that the road their lives have taken has been bumpy all along, with so many detours that being sidetracked has become the norm.

headline.main: Mother and Daughter Persevere Despite Health Problems
headline.print_headline: Mother and Daughter Persevere Despite Health Problems

abstract: Amid the economic downturn, the number of donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has soared by 53 percent over last year’s campaign.
snippet: Amid the economic downturn, the number of donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has soared by 53 percent over last year’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: Penelope Starr had read The New York Times Neediest Cases articles for at least a decade. Every year, she told herself she would contribute. Every year, she did not write a check.

headline.main: In a Time of Crisis, More Donors Decide to Give to the Needy

abstract: Agency funded by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is helping immigrant couple from Ukraine survive in New York; photos (M)
snippet: Agency funded by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is helping immigrant couple from Ukraine survive in New York; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: For a week after winning green cards in a United States immigration lottery, Boris and Luba Umansky of Zaporozhe, Ukraine, agonized over their good fortune. ''I could not eat,'' Mr. Umansky said. ''I could not sleep. To go, not to go. To stay, not to stay. We didn't know what to do.''

headline.main: From Ukraine, With Cab Fare And Hope, But Not Much Else
headline.print_headline: From Ukraine, With Cab Fare And Hope, But Not Much Else

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

abstract: A little over a year ago, a typical morning for Maya V. meant waking up, getting dressed and barely uttering a word to her parents before leaving her Brooklyn home to meet her friends.         Her parents thought she was going to school, but instead the 15-year-old Ukrainian immigrant was leading a double life. She started cutting classes at school and in six months, she dropped out altogether. She spent her days smoking and drinking with friends, and her nights in dance clubs. Sometimes, she would not return home at all.
lead_paragraph: A little over a year ago, a typical morning for Maya V. meant waking up, getting dressed and barely uttering a word to her parents before leaving her Brooklyn home to meet her friends.

abstract: Violence forced Kaltum Mohamed and her family to flee Darfur and later Libya. Now she has her own catering business that specializes in Sudanese cuisine.
snippet: Violence forced Kaltum Mohamed and her family to flee Darfur and later Libya. Now she has her own catering business that specializes in Sudanese cuisine.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Kaltum Mohamed took one last look at the inside of her home in the Darfur region of Sudan and closed the front door. She took the hands of her children, then 5 and 3, and walked away.
